conclusion: The conductor rod MN moves along vertical rails, there's a uniform magnetic field B pointing into the plane, the rod has mass m and resistance per unit length r, the distance between rails is l, the height difference between MN and BD is l, and the rod reaches a constant speed before arriving at BD.
When the rod moves through the magnetic field, it will experience gravitational force downward and electromagnetic force upward, opposing the motion.
The gravitational force on the rod is F_g = mg.
The emf induced in the rod is \( \mathcal{E} = Blv \).
The resistance of the rod is \( R = rl \).
The current in the rod is \( I = \frac{Blv}{rl} = \frac{Bv}{r} \).
The electromagnetic force on the rod is \( F_{em} = \frac{B^2l v}{r} \).
When the rod reaches constant speed, the forces balance: \( mg = \frac{B^2l v}{r} \).
